user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_write:
```c
int metal_io_block_write(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       const void *restrict src, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	const unsigned char *source = src;
	int retlen;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_write) {
		retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		while ( len && (
			((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)) ||
			((uintptr_t)source % sizeof(int)))) {
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
			ptr++;
			source++;
			len--;
		}
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
					source += sizeof(int),
					len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = *(const unsigned int *)source;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, source++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_io_block_write:
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);

int metal_io_block_write(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       const void *restrict src, int len)
explanation:
I did not include other fragments for investigation because they do not appear to conflict with MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13. Specifically:

- The src parameter and its local alias are already const-qualified ("const void *restrict src" and "const unsigned char *source = src;"), so they comply with the requirement that pointers point to const-qualified types when possible.

- The local pointer 'ptr' is used as a write target throughout the function (the code stores through ptr), so making the pointed-to type const would be incompatible with the intended writes; therefore those write operations and the casted assignment expressions that store through ptr are not candidates for const-qualification.

- The pointer casts on the right-hand side use const-qualified types (e.g. "(const unsigned int *)source"), which is consistent with the rule.

The three fragments reported should be inspected to determine whether the region descriptor pointer (io), the returned virtual pointer (metal_io_virt -> assigned to ptr) and the way io is passed into ops.block_write could/should use const-qualified pointer types (or whether the called ops require non-const). These are the locations most relevant to Rule 8.13 in the provided code.
